ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The weekly homework assignments were "designed" to take 6 hrs to complete, according to the instructor. However, they usually took up to 10-12 hrs to complete. The workload for this course was very heavy.
Question 7: Tomlin is great: funny, easygoing, responsive, knowledgeable, helpful, earnest... just a pleasure. He's also a GIS machine, the man thinks in spatial data.

This course was a disappointment. Although the instructor was entertaining, it stops there. There was little or no application to forestry and environmental studies. The assignments were not engaging and the instructor communicated his expectations poorly.
The course moved to quickly for anyone to have a firm grasp and understanding of what we were doing. Would be better to go slower and really solidly learn and understand what we were doing.

The GIS (Raster) was the best class i have taken this semester. The instructor is exceptional and insightful and very responsive. However, the work load is lot more and you can spend days working on it.

I'm torn over this class. I wish there had been a less intense GIS course at FES, perhaps one that is half raster, half vector, maybe focused on the practical applications rather than the theory and math (which, by and large, was over my head). I didn't get much out of class because when I tried to follow his actions using the software on the overhead, I couldn't listen, and when I listened but didn't follow his actions, I had no idea how to recreate what he was doing. It was just doing the assignments that taught me everything, and learning from my peers.This course actually challenged me in ways that most FES courses do not. It was something I wasn't comfortable with that I had to dink around with for hours.I guess I'm glad I can put GIS on my resume now, but I know I will never be a GIS mapper, and it prevented me from taking other classes that would have been more applicable to my areas of interest.

Question 2 - instructor tended to answer student questions with cryptic answersQuestion 3 - class assignments took waaay longer than 6 hours, and even when I spent 12 hours, I still got an average grade. However, I appreciated the open-endedness of the homework format. I think I learned a lot more than I would have through a typical GIS follow-the-directions format.

this is not a class that technically falls within my "interests" or area of study, but i think this is a useful skill to have, and provides tool by which to read and interpret data.- professor tomlin is highly knowledgeable, and presented lecture material in a very organized fashion, but i did not tend to absorb from being shown operations on the computer. learning mostly happened through assignments- in terms of workload, assignments took significantly longer than purported.

Professor Tomlin is unlike any professor I've ever had. I was incredibly impressed with his lecture style. He has a uniquely fresh way of explaining geographical concepts which I greatly appreciated. He is also amazingly responsive. For someone who spends only 14 hours a week in New Haven, he was much more accessible via email than most other professors are in person.
The TA for this course was not as accessible as the one from Modeling Geographic Objects. Her office hours were not at convenient times, and when I had a question for her she could not help.

The Prof is clearly very knowledgeable about the subject matter. He is brilliant, but sometimes I think he forgets that some of us are learning this material for the first time and perhaps he could slow down a little and teach the same tools/operations for 2 lectures at a time rather than introducing new material every class.
Dana's passion and his creative class assignments that were fun and challenging.

Getting hands-on experience using GIS, and actually finding that I understood more and more as the class progressed, and that my mind was starting to work in a way that could make use of its best qualities.
the instructor's mastery of the material.
Learning about how to apply GIS to make land use plans and to solve real life problems
lectures were very helpful in understanding the system
The instructor has an amazing knowledge of GIS and is a very effective professor.
Responsive instructor.
Its conceptual underpinning which allowed a flawless application of GIS fundamentals and understanding throughout our varied interests.
The homework! While the map assignments took a long time, I had a great time doing them, and I learned more through the process of the homeworks than I would have without them.
This is one of the few courses at FES where you learn a specific, marketable, technical skill, and I wish there were courses like this one in that way.
The knowledge you gain in learning this application is helpful in data analysis and interpretation.
The classes were interesting
the instructor, the assignments, the notes, the format of the class
I learned a lot from the homework assignments
professor tomlin is responsive and knowledgeable, helpful to students (and flexible on deadlines), and accommodating to student schedules.
The professor is very responsive in answering questions.
The professor is very good at explaining concepts by using colorful analogies. The assignments were challenging and required students to grapple with the material.
Hands on experience on mapping

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: More focus on application, less on theory. Teach it in a lab with computers so we can follow along and know what buttons to press. lets discuss theory after we've learned how we can use the program. No need to be in class for 3 hrs talking theory and allowing people to fall asleep when we could be following along on how to use the program=-which is the biggest take away from a gis course--normally.

I think the course should be taught in a computer lab. It's very difficult to listen to the Prof lecture about how to do something on the computer without practicing it as you go. I understand you can bring your computer to class, but it's very difficult to follow him because often he would just talk about how to use a certain operation but he wouldn't actually show it on the monitor.I understand that the Prof was trying to get us to think creatively about GIS, but seeing as it was my first GIS course, I think I would have responded much better if he had just given us assignments with step by step instructions. It's difficult as it is to understand how to use the operations and the software. Adding another level of complexity by forcing us to think about how to use these tools creatively might be better suited for a higher level (not intro) class.
the two or three assignments that were so difficult that you scratched at your eyes until 5 in the morning without making progress
Assignments and readings tend to be very very vague.
This is a course that needs complete restructuring and application to the environmental sciences.
perhaps some modules that are field specific, like epidemiology and environmental hazards, etc. to help show more applied uses of GIS
I think that the instructor could add some hours at the lab practicing the software.
Better course materials. They were v. difficult to understand.

The assignments were sort of canned in the sense that the data was all correctly formatted and compatible. My sense is that in real world projects the data has all sorts of incompatibilities that have to be fixed up. I would have preferred if at least a few of the assignments involved collecting publicly available data and massaging it as necessary to make it useful, then doing something with it. I understand that this would add a certain amount of complexity for both the student and teacher but I think it would be worth the extra effort to have some realistic experience.
The TA sessions never worked for me. The instructor has to make that one of the TA session is either on Friday or one of the weekend.
i wouldn't change anything

- i found lectures dry and not as useful as hands on activity...- grading system is frustrating and feels fairly subjective.- assignments were highly time consuming/more time consuming than they were supposed to be... especially with a subjective grading system, this could be frustrating.

The class assignments should not be graded on a curve. We were supposed to spend no more than 6 hours on each assignment. However, most people started spending much longer than 6 hours on the assignment because of the "grade curve."... Thus it was soon the case that in order to avoid getting a bad grade you would be forced to spend more than 6 hours. The result is that people spent much longer than they should have, sometimes at the expense of other schoolwork or other learning. Most of the learning took place in the first 6 hours and these additional hours were not very useful.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: I did not go to any of the help sessions, so I cannot comment.

TA was helpful and available. Professor tended to come to campus on Thrs afternoons/nights, when I had class, so I wasn't able to ever take advantage of his help in person. He was very responsive on email.
instructor: lightning fast response
When contacting the instructor, I always heard back right away, often with helpful advice.
Dana is really responsive.
The instructor was always available for help, in person and via email. I wasn't aware we had a TA!
The availability was good but the quality was very poor, I feel that she needed more knowledge on the GIS tools.
excellent, always responding to emails within hours regardless of time
The instructor was more than helpful to answer all our questions. I always contacted him for help. The TA was also helpful but I don't think her knowledge of GIS was sufficient.
The instructor was v. responsive.I didn't attempt to work w. the TA.
Dana was very responsive. Clear and always on point.

Both were extremely responsive to emails and calls. Professor Tomlin was not on campus a lot, but he made himself available every week before and after class as well as another day for extra help. Big thumbs up for both.
Great! Xiaoyen was very available and helpful!
The instructor was always available via emails and lab.However, i had a schedule conflict with TA and could not meet her when needed.

Professor Tomlin was the most accommodating and willing professor to work with that I have had in my time here. He was a little harsh at times, but in the end he's very reasonable. I can tell he is brilliant, and I'm only sorry my brain had trouble wrapping around this subject matter so that I didn't ever have anything intelligent to say/ask him.
Both the instructor and TA were helpfull
adequate
TA was helpful at giving directions for troubleshooting, but I would have liked clearer explanations about why and how the troubleshooting worked.
high on both accounts
They are available to the largest extent.
Always very prompt and helpful replies.
The instructor was excellent on both accounts, but the TA was not.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I thought I'd learn enough to be able to operate the program so I would be able to cite familiarity in my resume and occasionally use the map for a think-tank style or consulting job--I would say the goal was not met.
I thought it would be applicable since I'm interested in urban planning, but this is more for people interested in land conservation and land use management.
Really useful for people in Architecture.
I am very happy to have been introduced to this material. It will serve me well in architecture, landscape architecture and land/real estate development.
I do not foresee ever using this course in the future and only took it to fulfill requirements.
As a natural resource manager, GIS would be helpful for me in terms of data analysis and interpretation.
It doesn't fit into my program at all. It was the only bin 7 that I would consider taking in my last semester. I don't know what else I would have taken for that bin though.

Prior to this course I had no experience with GIS. I do not know exactly how/if this will fit into my eventual career plans, but I do know that it has the potential to be an extremely valuable and useful tool, and I'm glad that I learned about it.
If I go into land use, agriculture, or conservation, I think GIS will be useful. At the moment I'm going into land use.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See response to question 15.
To learn how to use GIS and to fill the bin requirement associated with it.
to learn GIS fo career and art possibilities
I am an undergraduate in the EVST program, and am an International Studies major. This class allowed me to get a scientific skills credit, and I believe it will be useful in the future.
to gain a site analysis tool for use in architecture and landscape architecture.
I thought I would enjoy doing GIS work, but I found it tedious.
To learn how to use the GIS to model different environmental situations and to learn how to interpret information presented in GIS.
develop spatial analysis skills for use in epidemiology
I felt that it would be useful for my future career to learn how to use a program like this, that has so many possibilities.
To fulfill MEM requirements.
Recommended by a joint-degree Forester and Architect
To learn something useful, which I believe I did. Hope to use this more.
The wide application of GIS and its practicality is the reason for me taking this class.
BIN 7
Its a valuable tool
to fulfill a bin requirement, also because this seems like a useful subject to have some exposure to.
GIS is fun and I wanted to learn a practical skill.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not at all. I do not recommend this course if you are not intending on being a GIS technician or if GIS will not be your full time job. As environmental managers, you will need to know application, not theory.

I suppose I didn't have any strong expectations for the class. I just thought that I would gain a good understanding of the use and application of the software. I felt like the class moved so quickly and covered so much material, I probably won't be able to retain much of the skills I gained, unfortunately (unless I were in a field that used GIS on a daily basis, which I am not).
yes
GIS is not as user-friendly as I had hoped but the class made it more so.
yes.
exceeded them. I did not know when I signed up , that the instructor wrote the book.
Yes
yes and no, i learned a lot about the system, but could have a bit more guidance in application to my own interests. but, live and learn!
Yes it did.

The class was frustrating and time-consuming, and I do not foresee using the materials in the future. The instructor was encouraging and available so I had a positive experience in working w. him. Overall, it was just a very poor fit for my background and interests.
Certainly
Yes.
Yes.
It was as hard as everyone said it would be, and it took as long to wade through each homework as they warned.
Yes
Yes, I felt that I gained a solid grasp on the basics of raster-based GIS processing.
Yes!
It was harder than I anticipated in terms of the amount of time spent.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No. See questions above.
Please see answer above.
yes
Yes, although I am not as proficient as I'd like to be.
yes.
yes
More than I expected.
N/a.
Yes!
Yes.
Yes.

Yes. I can put GIS on my resume and at least talk about it semi-intelligently to someone who knows a bit about it. But I didn't have the extra time to devote to delving deep into the program and learning all the potentially cool applications of the software.
YEs
Yes

I feel like there are still many tools within ArcGIS I do not understand, and without learning a script I still don't understand how certain things work or how to customize a tool. That may be a topic for a more advanced course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Hard to coordinate. Extremely hard when the group was at another school (UPenn). We had to re-do their work and that week we had 24 hrs of GIS homework--at least.

The advantages were that I got to learn how to use GIS from my classmates, who often explained it more clearly than the professor did. The disadvantage was that it was difficult to coordinate times to work with other people (sometimes up to 8 ppland at UPenn). Since there was no syllabus, we didn't know when these group assignments would come up and if you had already arranged for weekend plans, it was very difficult to coordinate with other people.

The advantages were the real-life experience of using GIS in a team, as it often is used. The disadvantages were that if one section was more difficult than other, the weight came down unfairly on one member's shoulders.
It is difficult for the students from the Architecture school to work with the students from Forestry. Our schedules and expectations are totally different.
It broke up the monotony of the weekly homework assignments.
The assignments get more creative and encourages discussions of what we learned in class. I liked very much working with people from another university and/or schools.
good to learn what others thought of the process, and to improve collaboration skills.
Coordination was difficult but it gave us the opportunity to discuss informally what we got and didnt get.

It was difficult to coordinate everyone because of busy schedules and everything. But the group work was really good in that it reinforced the conceptual stuff we were learning (mainly, prescriptive modeling).

The group work was very useful in all the usual ways, plus it required us to figure out how to pass GIS data between people and computers, which is important. I thought the remote group work with UofP peeps was not very useful, but the group work within FES was.
The group session was very helpful in problem solving.

I was glad that we had the experience, but also glad it was only twice. I felt like I was pulling my team along on the first exercise, but that I myself didn't have enough knowledge to help us work efficiently and learn stuff.
Logistically it was very challenging to find times to get together, especially within the short time span of a week.
Less work overall for each person, but then everyone is waiting for other people to complete their tasks.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do not take it if you just want familiarity with the program.

I would say that this is very HW intensive and if the first couple of weeks are difficult for you, it will only get harder. Be prepared for the Prof to cover material quickly and to spend at least 10 hrs on each HW assignment.
Start the assignments earlier in the week, and do the addendums.

If you are an architecture student then be prepared to put in a lot more time into this course than you would for any of yourarchitecture electives. This class is a huge time drain, and can be taxing in this regard because of our schedules.
difficult but valuable assignments
Take the class, it's worth it.
Only take the class if you think you will have a need for GIS skills in your future career.
TAKE IT
Definitely, do not hesitate to talk to Professor Tomlin. He is super helpful and very approachable. Also, definitely start the maps early because they will take a looooong time.
Don't fall behind!Also, the first half of this class especially is a lot of work, so be sure you have time to put into it.

GIS is a very practical tool and very helpful to every natural resource managers. More so, learning this application would be an added bonus in your career.However, its a time consuming class and make sure you plan your classes really well. One can end up spending a whole day on a problem and end up not solving it. Good Luck.

Block off 6 hours a week to work on the homework, because if you don't it will be extremely difficult to find enough time in your schedule to complete the assignments. I found it difficult to use ArcGIs on my Mac, because it was confusing and annoying to be going back and forth between windows on the mac desktop and VMWare fusion and saving the files to the right place and opening the homework assignments, etc. Get your computer set up with Scott Rummage early on.
start weekly assignments AS EARLY AS POSSIBLE.

You should constantly evaluate whether or not it is worth it to you to spend more than 6 hours on the assignment, because you will undoubtedly end up doing it and perhaps regretting it on more than one occasion.
Start early on the homework assignments.
